author: SwarfegaGit
body:
# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
[System.Net.WebRequest]::DefaultWebProxy.Credentials = [System.Net.CredentialCache]::DefaultNetworkCredentials

(Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'https://google.com').StatusCode
```

# Expected behavior

```powershell
200
```

# Actual behavior

```none
Error message being thrown from network proxy

Authentication Required
You must be authenticated to access this URL.
```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->
```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0-preview.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0-preview.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17763
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

This works fine on the same machine using Windows PowerShell but doesn't work in PowerShell 6 or above.

comments.author: TomPeters
comments.body:
I'm encountering what I think is the same problem on `6.2.2`.

I have a system proxy configured, and I am trying to specify custom credentials for this proxy using the following snippet
```
$systemProxy = [System.Net.WebRequest]::GetSystemWebProxy()
$systemProxy.Credentials = New-Object System.Net.NetworkCredential($proxyUsername, $proxyPassword)
[System.Net.WebRequest]::DefaultWebProxy = $systemProxy
```

On Windows PowerShell, `Invoke-WebRequest` successfully uses this configuration. On PowerShell Core, I receive a `407` response from the proxy server.

Are there any workarounds or alternative ways of configuring an invocation of `Invoke-WebRequest` to use the system proxy with credentials? I can't set the `-Proxy` parameter on `Invoke-WebRequest` because this is a system proxy, so I don't know the literal proxy URL upfront.

comments.author: mikes-gh
comments.body:
I have exactly the same issue with PowerShell 6.2.3
Cache access denied using
```
[System.Net.WebRequest]::DefaultWebProxy.Credentials =[System.Net.CredentialCache]::DefaultNetworkCredentials
```

Windows Powershell 5.1 works fine

In PowerShell 6.2.3 I can use 

```
$PSDefaultParameterValues.Add('Invoke-WebRequest:Proxy','http://proxy') 
$PSDefaultParameterValues.Add('Invoke-WebRequest:ProxyUseDefaultCredentials',$true)
$PSDefaultParameterValues.Add('Invoke-RestMethod:Proxy','http://proxy') 
$PSDefaultParameterValues.Add('Invoke-RestMethod:ProxyUseDefaultCredentials',$true)
```

In my $PROFILE

But of course that only works for commands that support proxy parameters

edit

I also tried

```
(New-Object System.Net.WebClient).Proxy.Credentials = `
  [System.Net.CredentialCache]::DefaultNetworkCredentials
```

as per

https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-powershell/blob/master/docs-conceptual/azps-2.8.0/install-az-ps.md

which didnt work

comments.author: garethmorris78
comments.body:
I also have the same issue. Powershell Core is not working via a forward proxy with an authentication layer ( any attempt use commandlets that require internet access returns a 407; so Invoke-WebRequest, Find-Module, Install-Module etc ). Windows Powershell works fine using the Cred Cache:

```powershell
(New-Object System.Net.WebClient).Proxy.Credentials = `
  [System.Net.CredentialCache]::DefaultNetworkCredentials
```

Tried on Powershell Core 6.2.3 and 7.0.0 rc2 on Windows 10 Build 1909.
